text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Separatist Kurdish rebels kill nine civilians in southeast Turkey where they have been fighting for self-rule for 12 years.
- Former emergency rule governor and current True Path Party (DYP) deputy Unal Erkan calls on DYP leader Ciller to resign.

- Turkish car producers deliver a second report to Prime Minister Erbakan aimed at stopping a decree allowing duty-free car imports for expatriate workers who hold 50,000 marks in a Turkish bank account.
- The new legislative year is opened with celebrations in parliament reflecting the mosaic of Turkish society.
- The Islamist-led government prepares to open the doors of strictly secularist military academies to students who went to religious secondary schools.
- President Demirel affirms the continuation of secularism in Turkey at the opening of the parliamentary session following the summer recess.
- Telephone call prices go up eight percent.
- Amnesty International condemns the rebel Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) for killing civilians as it launches a worldwide campaign on human rights violations in Turkey.
- The general staff chief says the media has exaggerated his statements by saying they were warnings against an increasing risk to secularism in Turkey.
